title: Just got a  suspension for this !
body:

replies.body: You weren't punished because someone claimed you harassed them. The system investigated your behavior because someone claimed you harassed them. You were punished because you did harass them. You argued with your team the entire time, calling them "bronze," "clown," "garbage," "dweeb," "piece of shit," telling them they "must lead sad ...weak lives," announcing how you reported them, and so on.

>now i have a 14 day suspension..for this chat

 Which means you had two prior punishments, which I'd wager were for the same offense or just general flaming. Either way, you knew this behavior wasn't acceptable but you're still doing it under the guise that it's justified because _other people_ flamed you first. 

 Sorry, it doesn't work that way. Mute people who give you a hard time and then report them at the end of the game.

>thanks riot for perpetuating a victim culture where any one can just say someone harassed them and they get banned.

 Or they're trying to create an environment where nobody should flame and they're not treating you as a "victim" since you're guilty of the exact same thing the flamer was guilty of. 

 Bottom line is that _you're_ responsible for _your_ behavior. If you can't control yourself when someone is giving you a hard time, you're going to get another punishment and it **will** be a permanent ban, no matter how severe you think it is.

 Good luck.

First off, you're not defending yourself here, you're retaliating: there's a difference.

Second off, from [Ulanopo's Knowledge Base](http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=4086541&page=5#post43468465): 

>**I should be allowed to speak however I like to people who started it or are griefing me.
I was provoked or taunted. I should be allowed to defend myself.
Why did you vote to punish me when others were behaving worse?**

>You should know that Riot specifically instructs jurors to ignore most of the conduct of people in a case other than the accused. The reason for this is rather simple: rather than one person causing trouble, you now have two  or more. In my more cynical moments, I have phrased it thus:

>_Timmy, Tommy and Sarah are trapped in an elevator.
Timmy loses his temper and soils himself.
Tommy gets angry at the smell and decides to retaliate by soiling himself.
Now Sarah is trapped with two smelly idiots.
Dont be Timmy or Tommy. Stop ****ing your pants._

>An informal poll of the Tribunal regulars shows that most jurors are willing to excuse a certain amount of response to someone who is attacking you, but that it isnt considered an excuse for you to become toxic in response. You get MAYBE one or two lines of response. Anything more than that and youre part of the problem.

>From Lyte (link (http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?p=27540071#post27540071)):

>_**We strongly believe that it is not OK to retaliate.** If a player refuses to cooperate and says something negative, then players should ignore the player and report them after the game. Players can ignore or mute players by pressing the Mute button on the Scoreboard [when you hit TAB] in the game._

>Emphasis mine.

You getting harassed is not what banned you, it was your behavior in retaliation. 

Retaliation is different than defending yourself. Defending yourself would be muting them. 

If you have a problem with someone's behavior you report them. That's it. You don't use the existence of the report feature to try to one up them, you don't insult them back, and you don't continue the blame game. You just report them.

You're responsible for your behavior just as they are responsible for their's.  If you've recently been off a 25-game chat restriction I can see this getting you a 14-day ban.

> [{quoted}](name=AeroWaffle,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=Zxiqety0,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2019-03-28T16:00:10.466+0000)
>
> You getting harassed is not what banned you, it was your behavior in retaliation. 
> 
> Retaliation is different than defending yourself. Defending yourself would be muting them. 
> 
> If you have a problem with someone's behavior you report them. That's it. You don't use the existence of the report feature to try to one up them, you don't insult them back, and you don't continue the blame game. You just report them.
> 
> You're responsible for your behavior just as they are responsible for their's.  If you've recently been off a 25-game chat restriction I can see this getting you a 14-day ban.

Defending yourself is not muting. That's ignoring someone. But he could defend himself without flaming or insulting back.

> [{quoted}](name=OneMustFall,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=Zxiqety0,comment-id=00020000,timestamp=2019-03-28T17:59:01.720+0000)
>
> Defending yourself is not muting. That's ignoring someone. But he could defend himself without flaming or insulting back.

It's one way of defending yourself (at least in regards to chat harassment). Defending yourself implies that you're preventing harm in some way, which if the OP didn't like the chat they would be able to prevent further chat by muting.

> [{quoted}](name=AeroWaffle,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=Zxiqety0,comment-id=000200000000,timestamp=2019-03-28T18:01:06.224+0000)
>
> It's one way of defending yourself (at least in regards to chat harassment). Defending yourself implies that you're preventing harm in some way, which if the OP didn't like the chat they would be able to prevent further chat by muting.

I mean if we're using any kind of real life terms here, ignoring and walking away is the opposite of defending yourself. Muting is the closest thing to ignoring and walking away.

But if you want to get literal, getting into your car and driving away is defending yourself from the sound projectiles coming your way. Just doesn't make any sense to use the phrase "Defending yourself" in that context.

> [{quoted}](name=OneMustFall,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=Zxiqety0,comment-id=0002000000000000,timestamp=2019-03-28T18:11:16.531+0000)
>
> I mean if we're using any kind of real life terms here, ignoring and walking away is the opposite of defending yourself. Muting is the closest thing to ignoring and walking away.
> 
> But if you want to get literal, getting into your car and driving away is defending yourself from the sound projectiles coming your way. Just doesn't make any sense to use the phrase "Defending yourself" in that context.

But we're not in real life, different rules apply here because of how intangible everything is. 

If we were to liken this to real life, muting someone would be like placing this immediate sound-proof barrier that only blocks out their voice and sound. You don't leave, you're still there. And now their verbal harassment can't reach you no matter how hard they try. It's a form of preventive defense.

> [{quoted}](name=AeroWaffle,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=Zxiqety0,comment-id=00020000000000000000,timestamp=2019-03-28T18:23:24.380+0000)
>
> But we're not in real life, different rules apply here because of how intangible everything is. 
> 
> If we were to liken this to real life, muting someone would be like placing this immediate sound-proof barrier that only blocks out their voice and sound. You don't leave, you're still there. And now their sound can't reach you no matter how hard they try.

That would still qualify as ignoring someone, not defending yourself. Putting on your headphones while someone is going off on you is ignoring them.

Not that there's anything wrong with suggesting to ignore someone when they're being toxic. But I think it's confusing to equate that to defending yourself.
